name: Cumin (Jira)
description:
Cumin (Jira) is a spice widely used in cooking for its distinctive warm, earthy, and slightly peppery flavor. It is a popular ingredient in various cuisines, including Indian, Middle Eastern, and Mexican. Cumin is known for its aromatic qualities and is often used in spice blends, curries, and stews. Uses: Spice Mixes, Cooking, Tempering, Beverages.  Benefits:Rich in Antioxidants: Contains compounds that have antioxidant properties, helping to combat oxidative stress.Aids Digestion: Known for improving digestion and relieving bloating and indigestion.Supports Immunity: Contains iron and other minerals that support the immune system.Weight Loss: Cumin has been shown to aid in metabolism and weight management.Anti-Inflammatory: Cumin contains compounds that may reduce inflammation in the body.

name: Cinnamon (Daruchini) Whole
description:
This product is manufactured/packaged in Bangladesh and its raw materials are collected from Vieatnum. Cinnamon is used mainly as an aromatic condiment and flavoring additive in a wide variety of cuisines, sweet and savory dishes, breakfast cereals, snack foods, tea, and traditional foods. Ground cinnamon is composed of around 11% water, 81% carbohydrates (including 53% dietary fiber), 4% protein, and 1% fat.[36] In a 100-gram reference amount, ground cinnamon is a rich source of calcium (100% of the Daily Value (DV)), iron (64% DV), and vitamin K (30% DV).

name: Dried Chillies (Shukna Morich)
description:
Dried Chillies (known as Shukna Morich in South Asia) are whole chilies that have been dried to preserve their flavor and heat. These chillies come in various varieties, including red, green, and yellow, and are used to add spice, heat, and depth to a wide range of dishes. Dried chillies are commonly used in Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, and other South Asian cuisines for tempering (tadka), pickling, or as a base for sauces and curries. Uses: Tempering (Tadka), Curries and Sauces Pickles, Spice Blends, Snacks and Garnishes. Benefits:Rich in Vitamin C: Dried chillies are a good source of vitamin C, which helps boost immunity and skin health.Supports Metabolism: The capsaicin in dried chillies can increase metabolism and aid in weight management.Pain Relief: Capsaicin is known to have pain-relieving properties and is often used in topical creams for muscle and joint pain.Antioxidant Properties: The antioxidants in dried chillies help combat free radicals in the body and promote overall health.Digestive Aid: Dried chillies can improve digestion by increasing the production of digestive enzymes. Storage Instructions: Store in a dry place. After opening, transfer the dried chillies to an airtight container to preserve their flavor and aroma.

name: Fenugreek (Methi) Seed
description:
Fenugreek (Methi) Seeds are small, amber-colored seeds known for their distinctive, slightly bitter flavor and aromatic qualities. They are commonly used in Indian, Middle Eastern, and Mediterranean cuisines to add flavor to curries, spice blends, and pickles. Fenugreek is also celebrated for its numerous health benefits and is a key ingredient in many traditional remedies. Uses: Spice Cooking, Pickles, Sprouts, Infusions. Benefits:Improves Digestion: Fenugreek seeds are known for relieving digestive issues like bloating and indigestion.Supports Breastfeeding: Fenugreek is often used as a galactagogue to help increase milk production in nursing mothers.Blood Sugar Regulation: Fenugreek has been shown to help control blood sugar levels, making it beneficial for people with diabetes.Anti-Inflammatory: Contains compounds that may reduce inflammation and support joint health.Rich in Nutrients: High in fiber, iron, magnesium, and B-vitamins, supporting overall health.

name: Alu Bukhara
description:
This product is manufactured/packaged in Bangladesh and its raw materials are collected from Afganistan. Alu Bukhara, also known as plums, is a healthy food item. When dried, they are known as prunes. These sweet and juicy fruits are rich in vitamins K, C, and A, and contain antioxidants.Some varieties of plum fruit are sour, while others are sweet. Alu Bukhara is often used as an auxiliary flavor enhancer in biryanis and other dishes. Alu Bukhara provides minerals, iron, vitamin K, and potassium. Besides culinary uses, Alu Bukhara is also used in traditional medicine for various health benefits, including aiding digestion, preventing constipation, and improving bone health. The word Aloo is derived from the Persian word for plum, and “Bokhara” is named after the city of Bukhara in Uzbekistan. In short, Alu Bukhara means plum of Bukhara.

name: Nutmeg (Jayfal) Whole
description:
Nutmeg (known as Jayfal in South Asia) is a spice derived from the seed of the nutmeg tree (Myristica fragrans). The whole nutmeg seeds are aromatic and have a warm, sweet, and slightly spicy flavor, often used to enhance both sweet and savory dishes. Whole nutmeg is typically grated or ground just before use to retain its full flavor and aroma. It is commonly used in baking, beverages, and spice blends. Uses:Baking & Desserts: Nutmeg is commonly used in baked goods like cakes, cookies, pies, and pastries, particularly in spiced cakes, gingerbread, and pumpkin pie.Beverages: Nutmeg is often added to hot beverages like eggnog, chai, or mulled wine for added warmth and spice.Spice Blends: Nutmeg is a key component of many spice blends, such as garam masala, pumpkin pie spice, and mixed spice.Curries & Savory Dishes: Nutmeg can be grated and added to soups, curries, and stews for a rich, warming flavor.Garnish: Freshly grated nutmeg is often used as a garnish for desserts like custards, puddings, and ice cream. Benefits:Digestive Aid: Nutmeg can help soothe indigestion, reduce bloating, and improve overall digestive health.Rich in Antioxidants: Nutmeg contains compounds that act as antioxidants, helping protect the body from oxidative stress and inflammation.Pain Relief: Nutmeg has been used traditionally as a natural remedy for pain relief, especially for headaches, toothaches, and muscle pain.Improves Sleep: Nutmeg is sometimes used as a natural sleep aid, helping to promote relaxation and improve the quality of sleep.Boosts Brain Function: The antioxidants and other compounds in nutmeg may support cognitive function and improve memory and focus.

name: Black Cardamom (Kalo Elachi) Whole
description:
Black Cardamom (known as Kalo Elachi in South Asia) is a large, dark, and aromatic spice that belongs to the ginger family. Unlike green cardamom, black cardamom has a smoky, earthy, and slightly pungent flavor. It is often used in savory dishes, especially in South Asian and Middle Eastern cuisines, to add depth and complexity to curries, stews, rice dishes, and spice blends. The pods are typically larger, with a dark brown to black color, and contain small black seeds inside. Uses:Curries & Gravies: Black cardamom is commonly added to savory curry dishes, stews, and gravies for a smoky and aromatic flavor.Rice Dishes: Black cardamom is used in rice dishes like biryani, pilaf, and khichdi to enhance the fragrance and flavor.Spice Blends: Black cardamom is an important component in spice blends like garam masala, biryani masala, and other regional spice mixtures.Marinades & Sauces: It can be added to marinades for meats, poultry, or vegetarian dishes, giving them a unique, smoky flavor.Pickles & Stews: It is used in pickles and slow-cooked stews to add a rich, deep flavor. Benefits:Digestive Aid: Black cardamom is known to promote healthy digestion, alleviate indigestion, and help with bloating and gas.Anti-Inflammatory Properties: The spice has anti-inflammatory effects and may help reduce inflammation in the body.Improves Respiratory Health: Black cardamom has been traditionally used to treat respiratory issues like asthma, bronchitis, and cough due to its cooling and soothing properties.Rich in Antioxidants: Black cardamom contains antioxidants that help combat oxidative stress and protect cells from damage.Supports Heart Health: The spice may help reduce blood pressure and improve overall heart health when consumed regularly.

name: Mustard Seed (Red)
description:
Red Mustard Seeds are small, round seeds with a slightly pungent, sharp flavor. They are commonly used in South Asian and Mediterranean cuisines, where they add a unique depth of flavor to a variety of dishes. Red mustard seeds are often used in tempering (tadka) to infuse their flavor into oil, which is then added to curries, soups, and pickles. They are also a key ingredient in many spice blends. Uses: Tempering (Tadka), Pickles, Curries and Stews, Spice Blends,  Salads and Garnishes. Benefits:Rich in Nutrients: Mustard seeds are high in minerals such as calcium, iron, and magnesium.Promotes Digestion: Known to aid in digestion and improve gut health.Anti-Inflammatory Properties: Contains compounds that have anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects.Rich in Fiber: Helps support digestive health and may aid in weight management.Heart Health: Mustard seeds are a source of omega-3 fatty acids, which support cardiovascular health.

name: Poppy Seed (Posto Dana)
description:
Poppy Seeds (known as Posto Dana in South Asia) are small, round seeds harvested from the opium poppy plant (Papaver somniferum). These seeds are commonly used in cooking for their subtle, nutty flavor and crunchy texture. Poppy seeds are often incorporated into curries, sauces, salads, and sweets, and are a staple in many South Asian, Middle Eastern, and Mediterranean cuisines. They can also be ground into a paste to be used in various dishes. Uses:Curries & Gravies: Poppy seeds are ground into a paste and added to curry gravies, especially in Bengali cuisine, to create a smooth, rich texture.Sweets & Desserts: Poppy seeds are used in traditional desserts like Posto Raita, Posto Patishapta, and sweet rolls.Baking: Poppy seeds are often sprinkled over bread, muffins, or cookies to add a crunchy texture and subtle flavor.Spice Blends: Poppy seeds are used in spice mixes and are a key ingredient in various regional spice blends in Indian and Middle Eastern cooking.Smoothies & Drinks: They can be added to smoothies for an extra crunch or used in certain traditional drinks. Benefits:Rich in Nutrients: Poppy seeds are packed with essential minerals such as calcium, iron, magnesium, and zinc, supporting bone health and overall well-being.Promotes Digestion: The fiber in poppy seeds aids in digestion and helps regulate bowel movements.Rich in Antioxidants: Poppy seeds contain antioxidants that help fight free radicals and reduce inflammation in the body.Supports Skin Health: The oils in poppy seeds are known to help with skin health and provide a natural glow.Good Source of Energy: Poppy seeds provide a natural energy boost due to their high content of healthy fats, protein, and carbohydrates.

name: Mace Whole
description:
Mace is a spice derived from the outer covering of the nutmeg seed. It has a similar flavor profile to nutmeg, but it is more delicate and aromatic. The whole mace consists of dried red arils (the outer coating of the nutmeg seed) and is used in cooking for its warm, slightly sweet, and aromatic flavor. Mace is often used in both sweet and savory dishes, especially in South Asian, Middle Eastern, and European cuisines. It is available in whole pieces or ground form. Uses:Baking & Sweets: Mace is commonly used in baking and is a key ingredient in spiced cakes, cookies, and pastries. It also pairs well with desserts such as custards and puddings.Curries & Gravies: Mace can be added to curries, stews, and sauces, particularly in dishes with rich, creamy gravies, to enhance their flavor.Spice Blends: Mace is often used in spice blends like garam masala and other regional mixtures for savory dishes.Beverages: Mace is sometimes used in beverages like mulled wine, eggnog, and chai for added warmth and spice.Rice Dishes: Whole mace is often used to flavor rice dishes, adding an aromatic note to pilafs and biryanis. Benefits:Rich in Antioxidants: Mace contains compounds that have antioxidant properties, helping to protect cells from damage caused by free radicals.Digestive Aid: Mace has been traditionally used to improve digestion, reduce bloating, and ease stomach discomfort.Anti-Inflammatory: Mace has natural anti-inflammatory properties, helping to reduce inflammation and promote overall health.Relieves Pain: Mace has been used in folk medicine to relieve pain and reduce symptoms of conditions like arthritis or toothache.Promotes Relaxation: Mace has mild sedative properties and is believed to help with relaxation, reduce stress, and improve sleep.

name: Ekata Fenugreek (Methi) Seed
description:
Fenugreek seeds, commonly known as Methi seeds, are native to western Asia and Southern Europe but they are widely grown and used in Indian cuisine. Bitter in taste, these seeds are highly valued for their medical qualities and multiple uses. Fenugreek seeds are often used to treat various ailments like diabetes and hypertension. Consuming 10 grams of fenugreek seeds soaked in hot water every day helps control type-2 diabetes. Traditionally it is also used to treat stomach upsets, heartburn, acid reflux, skin diseases, and kidney problems. It is a well-known alternative to allopathic medicines to improve breast milk production in lactating mothers. Another well-known use of methi seeds is to improve the testosterone hormone levels in men. All along, methi seeds have been added in small quantities to idli/dosa batter, rasam, and sambar powders, deals, and ground and added as thickening agents to currys.

name: Kabab Chini
description:
Kabab Chini 50 gm Details:Kabab Chini, also known as cubeb or tailed pepper, is a spice derived from the dried unripe fruits of the *Piper cubeba* plant. Native to Java and Sumatra in Indonesia, it is widely cultivated in other parts of Southeast Asia, India, and Malaysia. Kabab Chini is known for its aromatic and medicinal properties and is often used in Ayurvedic medicine. Ingredients:The key component of Kabab Chini is the dried cubeb berries, which contain bioactive compounds such as essential oils, resin, and cubebin. These contribute to its unique aroma and therapeutic properties. Uses:1. Culinary: It enhances the flavor of sweet and savory dishes and can be used as a spice in curries or desserts.  2. Medicinal: Known for digestive, anti-inflammatory, and respiratory benefits. It aids in treating bloating, indigestion, and respiratory congestion.  3. Therapeutic: Commonly used in Ayurveda for treating urinary and sexual health issues, and as an immune booster.  4. Cosmetic: Sometimes used in traditional cosmetics and perfumes for its aromatic qualities.

name: White Pepper Whole
description:
White Pepper is made from the same plant as black pepper, but it is processed differently. The outer black shell of the peppercorn is removed, leaving only the inner seed, which is light in color. White pepper has a milder, slightly fermented flavor compared to black pepper and is commonly used in lighter-colored sauces, soups, and dishes where a less intense pepper flavor is desired. It is a common ingredient in Chinese, Thai, and European cuisines. Uses: Sauces & Soups, Stir-fries & Wok Dishes,  Seasoning for Meats & Vegetables, Egg Dishes, Salads & Dressings. Benefits:Digestive Aid: White pepper is known to stimulate digestion, improve the absorption of nutrients, and alleviate indigestion.Rich in Antioxidants: Like black pepper, white pepper contains antioxidants that help protect the body from oxidative stress and free radical damage.Supports Respiratory Health: White pepper has been used traditionally to treat respiratory issues like coughs and congestion.Anti-Inflammatory: White pepper has natural anti-inflammatory properties that may help reduce pain and inflammation in the body.Weight Management: White pepper is sometimes used in weight management diets, as it may help increase metabolism and fat-burning processes.

name: Star Flower
description:
Star Flower, also known as Star Anise (Illicium verum), is a star-shaped spice that comes from the fruit of a tree native to northeastern Vietnam and southern China. The spice has a strong, sweet, and licorice-like flavor, similar to aniseed but more potent. Star Anise is commonly used in both sweet and savory dishes and is a key ingredient in Chinese five-spice powder and many Southeast Asian, Indian, and Mediterranean dishes. Uses:Spice Blends: Star Anise is a primary ingredient in Chinese five-spice powder and various spice mixes for stews, curries, and marinades.Baking & Desserts: It is used in baking, especially in recipes for gingerbread, cakes, and cookies, and in syrups and fruit preserves.Soups & Stews: Star Anise can be added to broths, soups, and stews to enhance the depth of flavor, especially in Chinese, Vietnamese, and Indian cuisines.Teas & Beverages: Star Anise is used in herbal teas and beverages like mulled wine, chai, and hot toddies.Pickles & Sauces: Star Anise is used in pickling brines and sauces for a fragrant and slightly sweet note. Benefits:Digestive Aid: Star Anise has been traditionally used to relieve indigestion, bloating, and gas. It also promotes overall digestive health.Rich in Antioxidants: Star Anise contains compounds that have antioxidant properties, helping to protect cells from damage caused by free radicals.Anti-Microbial Properties: The spice has natural anti-bacterial and anti-fungal properties, making it useful in maintaining oral hygiene and combating infections.Supports Respiratory Health: Star Anise is used in traditional medicine to treat respiratory issues like cough and bronchitis.Pain Relief: The active compounds in Star Anise can provide relief from muscle aches, headaches, and joint pain.

name: Betel Nut (Shupari)
description:
The chewing of betel nut quids dates to antiquity. In the 1st century AD, Sanskrit medical writings claimed that betel nut possessed 13 qualities found in the region of heaven. It is pungent, bitter, spicy, sweet, salty, and astringent. It was said to expel wind, kill worms, remove phlegm, subdue bad odors, beautify the mouth, induce purification, and kindle passion. Because of its CNS-stimulating effects, betel nut is used like the Western use of tobacco or caffeine. Arecoline is responsible for some of the effects of betel quid chewing, such as alertness, increased stamina, a sense of well-being, euphoria, and salivation. Chewing the nut stimulates the flow of saliva to aid digestion. Betel nut also has been used to stimulate the appetite. Nutritional facts/Ingredients :"Benefits: -Prevents oral cavities-Prevents dry mouth-Prevents stained teeth-Prevents gum infection-Reduces swelling in gums-Effectively battles indigestion-Powers up concentration levels-Prevents diarrhea-Heal's anemia and blood sugar-Pregnant Women should avoid eating it

name: Radhuni Seeds
description:
Radhuni, also known as Ajmod or white celery seeds, is a popular spice used primarily in Bengali cuisine. It belongs to the Apiaceae family and its botanical name is *Trachyspermum roxburgianum*. The seeds are slightly larger than ajwain and have a flavor profile that blends the sharpness of ajwain with a mild aftertaste of fennel seeds. They are commonly used in Bengali Panch Phoron (five-spice mix) and other traditional dishes. Weight: Available in a variety of pack sizes, including the common 100 gm pack. Ingredients: Radhuni seeds, also known as white celery seeds, are the sole ingredient. These seeds are rich in essential oils, which contribute to their strong aroma and flavor. Use: Radhuni seeds are used in cooking to enhance the flavor of dishes, particularly in Bengali stews, and curries, and as part of the Panch Phoron mix. They are also considered to have medicinal properties, traditionally used to aid digestion and relieve colic.

name: Khaas Food Black Seed Powder
description:
Manufacturer: Khas food    Khaas Food Black Seed Powder  Black seed is known as the “seed of blessing”. Inside these tiny little seeds is contained a highly complex chemical structure that includes over one hundred different chemical constituents such as abundant sources of essential fatty acids.  Typically, the oil derived from the seeds is used for medicinal purposes, and the spicy little seeds are used in cooking: curries, pastries, and Mediterranean cheeses. In Bangladesh, the back seed is used in different delicious food and drinks making like Singara, Samucha, tea etc  Prevents diabetes, high blood pressure, anti-asthmatic effects, throat pain, colon cancer growth.
